Award.AwardTitle: Voltage Stability and Control in Smart Grids

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Abstract
Voltage Stability and Control in Smart Grids

Objective
The objective of this project is to develop advanced voltage control methods for future smart grids. The focus is transient and short-duration voltage instability which will become more prevalent in future distribution systems with high penetration of renewable generation. The approach is to first identify possible forms of voltage instability by experiments on a virtual and a hardware-in-the-loop system test-bed. Typical instability behaviors will be characterized by proper system models to determine their origins and most effective mitigation methods. Distributed voltage control techniques are then developed for representative renewable sources and energy storage devices which function autonomously but collectively support system stability. The developed control techniques will be tested and demonstrated on the hardware-in-the-loop system test-bed.

Intellectual Merit
This research explores an interdisciplinary area among power systems, power electronics, and control, and addresses several fundamental modeling and control issues related to renewable energy grid integration, efficient energy utilization, and smart grids. The focus on analytical methods and tools combined with experimental work on system test-beds ensures general applicability of the research while providing practical solutions to real-world problems.

Broader Impact
The control techniques to be developed in this project will help transform today's largely passive, unidirectional, and protection-centric power distribution network into a smart grid capable of accommodating any amount of renewable energy anywhere and at any time. This will reduce the reliance on fossil fuel, improve national energy security, and enable a more sustainable economy. Close partnership with the industry provides a unique pathway for technology transfer and knowledge dissemination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was motivated by the anticipation that increasing use of power electronics in power systems would lead to new and more wide-spread voltage stability and power quality problems. Unlike conventional electromechanical and electromagnetic energy conversion devices, such as generators and transformers that use slow or no active control, modern power electronics rely on fast control to support high-frequency switching operation in order to reduce size and the use of raw materials. Such fast controls, coupled with the inherently nonlinear characteristics of power electronic circuits, lead to complex dynamics and create potentials for control interaction and instability problems in a frequency range that extends beyond the fundamental and well into the electromagnetic transient (EMT) frequency region of conventional power systems where there used to be no active control, hence no stability problems. Addressing such high-frequency stability problems requires new models and tools, as the existing stability theory based on phasor-models cannot be applied at frequencies close to or above the fundamental frequency. On the other hand, EMT models are almost always nonlinear such that linearization and small-signal analysis are necessary for studying any practical stability problems at the system level. A fundamental problem arises when one attempts to linearize an EMT model because of the presence of variables (currents, voltages, and control signals) that vary with time (at 50 or 60 Hz).

A major outcome of this research is new frequency-domain modeling and small-signal analysis methods that can be applied to study control interaction and system stability in the EMT frequency range. At the core of the approach is a direct frequency-domain linearization technique to develop small-signal models for power electronic circuits and control operating with ac inputs and/or outputs. The results are expressed in the form of frequency-dependent sequence impedance models that are valid from subsynchronous to the EMT frequency range. To use these sequence impedance models in system stability analysis, the impedance-based stability theory, which has been used in power electronics to study dc-dc converters and dc power system stability, is generalized to three-phase power systems also based on sequence decomposition. The end result is a small-signal representation of a three-phase system by a positive-sequence and a negative-sequence subsystem, and a stability criterion for each sequence subsystem based on the input and output impedance measured at the system interface.

Specific outcome of the project includes analytical sequence impedance models developed for various power electronic converters and systems commonly used in power systems, including PV inverters and type-IV wind turbines, converter-machine systems such as type-III turbines, and HVDC converters using conventional line commutated converter, two-level voltage-source converter, and modular multilevel converter technologies. Each developed model has been extensively validated by experimental measurement as well as numerical simulation using detailed device and circuit models. The analytical form of these models makes them universally applicable and useful for both analysis and design purposes. Additional outcome of the project includes successful application of the proposed theory in solving practical stability and resonance problems that are increasingly common in renewable energy and HVDC systems. A large number of case studies have been performed to demonstrate the application in PV, wind, and HVDC systems, including offshore wind farms with HVDC transmission. Resonance is identified as one of the most common problems, and different techniques to damp system resonances have been developed and demonstrated at various scales. The theory and models developed in this project have also been tested by industry in several high-profile incidents in Europe and China. The successful applications in turn have accelerated the acceptance of the proposed theory and method by industry. A number of manufacturers and transmission system operators are incorporating sequence impedance modeling and analysis as part of new product and system development.
